subtitle: The inaugural issue of the New Thinking Allowed
magazine was just released on March 1st.
You can download a free PDF copy from the New Thinking Allowed Foundation website.
That's newthinkingallowed.org.
You can even order a printed copy from nta-magazine.magcloud.com.
Thinking Allowed – conversations on the
leading edge of knowledge and discovery with
psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove.
Hello and welcome.
I'm Jeffrey Mishlove.
Today we will be exploring consciousness and reality.
With me is Professor Tom Lombardo.
He is the author of Future Consciousness – A Path to Purposeful Evolution.
He is also the author of The Evolution of
Future Consciousness and Contemporary Futurist
Studies and Mind Flight – A Journey into the Future.
He is the director of the Center for Future Consciousness in Tempe, Arizona.
Welcome, Tom.
Thank you, Jeff.
It's a pleasure to be with you.
A pleasure to be with you.
When we talk about consciousness and reality,
we're looking at probably the most elusive
problem in all of philosophy.
It's definitely one of the oldest problems in modern philosophy at least.
Going back to Rene Descartes for sure and his dualistic philosophy of separating mind
from physical matter and separating them in a way that created what came to be referred
to as the hard problem, which is how consciousness,
which seems to have one set of properties,
is connected with physical matter and the physical body, which has a different set of
properties.
Right.
I've done quite a few interviews on this topic and one of the points it comes across
is that the average person, not a philosopher,
but is sort of instinctively a dualist.
Yes, I would imagine that that's true.
They're instinctively a dualist until they start thinking about what the implications
of that are.
For example, how does a thought get my
physical muscles to move and my body to move?
Or how does an electrochemical activity in
the brain produce an experience of the smell
of a rose?
Then it becomes a challenge to try to make that ontological jump in either direction
from mind to matter and matter to mind.
Well, I know Max Planck, the founder of quantum
theory, one of the founders, one of the important
founders of quantum theory, puzzled over this
because of the observer problem in quantum
mechanics and he concluded you just can't get underneath consciousness.
Yes, it is a difficult thing to get underneath.
In fact, a good quick story to bring this
point home is when I was in college, I remember
first reading Bishop Barclay and Bishop Barclay's
theory of perception and Bishop Barclay presented
to me what seemed to be a very convincing argument, which is that whatever I refer to
as something meaningful, something I can know,
always seems to be an experience, even things
like the experience of seeing the color red or feeling the solidity of an object or of
smelling some delicious food, for example, in
that I can never say anything that's meaningful
beyond my conscious experiences.
So to assume that there is something beyond
my conscious experiences is a leap of faith.
And so the notion of physical matter doesn't seem to make any sense.
What makes sense is that the totality of my existence, everything I am, reduces down to
conscious experiences and whether I'm doing
quantum physics or whether I'm doing biology
or whether I'm talking to you right now, it
all is a complex array of conscious experiences
with various perceptual emotional qualities to them.
I've often thought of Bishop Barclay, for whom the city of Berkeley, California was
named was a very logical thinker.
His argument seems on the one hand very
unsettling and on the other hand irrefutable.
Yes, it does seem irrefutable, except my intuition was that he was the challenge.
How can one come up with a convincing alternative
to Barclay's idealism, which is everything
that exists is consciousness and ideas and consciousness.
And ultimately the mind of God.
And ultimately the mind of God.
And he had a slip in the mind of God because
when I'm not looking at or experiencing the
red rose, which is an idea according to him, where is that idea of a red rose?
Well no one is looking at it, well it's in the mind of God.
That was his jump.
Well anyway, I saw Bishop Barclay as a epistemological
and an ontological challenge because he was
so convincing.
How does one come up with an alternative?
Because intuitively it did not make sense to me to think that that physical matter in
some sense whatsoever is nothing but a
camera, an illusion, and it's just all mind.
Now undoubtedly you're aware of the famous
conversation between Boswell and Johnson about
Bishop Barclay.
Oh yes, of course.
Yes, right.
And Boswell of course and Johnson actually, Johnson's reputation which was to kick the
rock was a misconception.
It was a refutation that in no sense whatsoever
refuted Barclay because Barclay would have
simply said that the kicking of the rock was
a combination of a visual perception and a
textual and a haptic perception and so the totality of the experience of kicking the
rock was all in your mind.
That was it.
So he was never able to get to the rock so to speak.
Right.
But Johnson undoubtedly felt the common sense trumps logic.
Yes, yes.
I guess he could think that and in fact what,
200 years later the Cambridge philosopher
G. E. Moore attempted to prove the existence
of the external world using his hands and
it was almost like a similar kind of argument.
Like here is my hand, my hand is a physical
object, I can see it, therefore the external
physical world exists.
Now maybe I'm oversimplifying G. E. Moore but in fact it came down to a similar kind
of argument.
Well, I gather that the real refutation of
Bishop Barclay comes from taking his argument
to its logical conclusion which is solipsism.
You could take it to that conclusion.
You could take it to the conclusion that each
of us individually exists in our own bubble
of consciousness, we can never go beyond that
sphere or bubble of consciousness and therefore
right now I'm simply talking to this image in my bubble of consciousness which I refer
to as Jeff and in your bubble of consciousness
you're talking to this image that you refer
to as Tom but Tom and Jeff never really make
contact with each other, we're each in our
own little spheres and that in particular concern me because, and although this may
be not exactly a logical argument, it means
that you can never have intimacy and resonance
and love with another distinctive human being
because each of us is trapped in our own little
solipsistic existence.
Solipsism could lead to the conclusion which
is rather grandiose and paranoid that perhaps
the only thing that really exists is my own consciousness and to infer there's anything
else is a jump, is another leap of fate.
So I'm the totality of existence, yes.
Which is what mystics say, ultimately, and I don't think they mean it in a solipsistic
way.
They're referring to the interconnectedness of everything.
Well that's a totally different kind of thing then.
The interconnectedness of everything must mean
that there are things that are interconnected
when one starts from idealism, all I know is what I experience, to I'm trapped in my
consciousness then there are not these other
things that I can legitimately talk about.
If I include the interconnectedness of other
things then I'm assuming that there is a reality
beyond this thing here and that somehow we're connected together.
And I think that in fact we are connected
together and I think in fact that we actually
do resonate, interface with each other, and we interface with each other in a conscious
intimate way.
More so the better we get to know each other.
But I don't think we are trapped.
But Barclay and Descartes early on led to
this possibility that all we could know would
be our conscious experiences and that the physical world is nothing but an inference.
And that creates a puzzle.
You describe a time in your life when trying
to think through this puzzle made you dizzy.
Yes, in fact it's made me dizzy on several occasions.
And I would use Bishop Barclay as an example
where I did get dizzy because if you grow
up and you assume that there is this physical
world that you see around you that you exist
within and it's intuitively perfectly obvious
that this exists and then somebody presents
a convincing argument that in fact what you thought all of this was that doesn't really
exist in the way you thought it did, then it feels like the floor and the ground has
literally been pulled out from under your feet and reality goes into a flip-flop.
You have a gestalt switch.
You have a fundamental paradigm shift in consciousness
where everything is seen differently if you
buy into Bishop Barclay.
And that was only one case where you can get that kind of experience of dizziness.
I know Immanuel Kant had a similar line of thinking.
Yeah, Immanuel Kant had a similar line of thinking
insofar as he argued, all I can meaningfully
talk about are phenomena and phenomena are interpreted in terms of the categories of
understanding and the pure intuitions of space
and time, but those categories of understanding
and intuitions do not necessarily apply to the thing in itself.
But he believed that there was a thing in
itself beyond experience that we could never
know.
And I felt like Kant got himself into a meaningless
discussion that actually contradicted his
principles by even making reference to the
notion of the thing in itself, since according
to him the only thing you could meaningfully
talk about were your phenomenal experiences.
So you can't even say that there is a thing
in itself, although he says he believes there
is.
He thinks that there is something out there.
Thing in itself is a funny term.
It's a term that seems like it means something,
but when you start to think about it, what
is the thing in itself?
Because that would mean understanding its
intrinsic nature independent of any relationships
it has with anything else.
Does that make any sense?
Well, it might make some sense.
I'm tossing it out.
Yes.
Well, for example, here's a thing.
Yes, yes, there it is.
It exists independent of you or me.
That's what we believe if we don't buy Bishop Barclay.
Okay, yes, yes.
And of course it means something unique to me, it might mean something unique to you,
but it's a thing in and of itself.
You and I might be able to agree to that.
Oh, I think we do agree that it's a thing in and of itself, but if we're following
his logic, Barclay's logic, then each of us is
making reference to a distinctive perceptual
experience when we, in our field of view, our
finger points to another object, the image
of this sculpture, in our field of view and our phenomenal experience.
And so when I do this to point to the thing in itself, I'm actually just experiencing
my experience of my finger, my experience of
the statue, and you're doing the same thing.
And we haven't really got at then this presumed
thing in itself, which is where Barclay says
it becomes meaningless then.
Both of us think there's something there independent of us experiencing it.
So subsequent to Barclay and Kant and Descartes,
we have the development of perceptual psychology.
We know how the eye works, we know how the ear
works, and we have a much greater understanding
of how the human consciousness incorporates sensory information.
Good, good.
And that's a good lead-in to actually adding
to the puzzle, because the study of the brain,
the nervous system, sensory stimulation, human
psychology indicates that those systems are
selectively sensitive to only narrow ranges of stimulus energy.
So the totality of reality, a lot of it is filtered out.
Which would be in agreement with Kant's categorical...
Yes, right.
A lot of it is filtered out, yes, okay, number one.
And secondly, we also know that the statue
from the study of physics and chemistry could
be analyzed at multiple levels of analysis
from its three-dimensional gestalt shape down
to vibratory patterns of electrons.
Now we do not see this as vibratory patterns of
electrons, we see it as a solid three-dimensional
shape, okay?
So we're only tapping into a small selected
aspect of reality through our sensory systems,
and then on top of all of that, our sensory
systems, our perceptions and sensory experiences
are constantly being interpreted and organized
and made sense of through our concepts, our
memories, our theories of reality.
So by the time we get to our conscious experience of the statue, it has been...
We have a selective, perspectival, interpreted
conscious reality, which is not in any sense
whatsoever, some absolute multi-perspective,
omnidirectional, intrinsic thing in itself.
Could never be.
It could never be.
Yes, it could never be.
Humans always have a perspective.
They always have a perspective, they always are selective.
We resonate in with certain things, we don't
resonate in with other things, we interpret
things different ways.
Somebody could look at that and see something
totally meaningless, somebody else will see
a work of art, and in fact, another thing that we all do, which is very significant
with respect to our interface with reality, is that we are active exploratory beings.
We don't sit still when we engage reality.
So if I want to get a better apprehension of that object, I begin to do this, which
is to look at it from multiple perspectives,
which enhances my perception of it.
And so just sitting there and letting reality,
so to speak, hit you in the face is not what
we do.
We select, we interpret, we explore, we manipulate,
and the more we do that, our perceptions become
clearer, but it definitely is not a passive,
just let reality hit me in my face experience.
Yes.
And I suppose another slant on it is, in theory, we
could build a computer and take every perspective
that humans have ever had on everything, put
it all into the mind of the computer, so the
computer might be able to begin to approach this idea of all perspectives at once.
Yeah.
It could approach it, but it'll never realize
it, and it never realizes it because perspective
is a dynamic gestalt.
And by that, I mean that it's not simply a set of points of observation.
It's a set of pathways of integrative observation.
We never see anything in a moment.
We always see things across time, and we never
see things at a hypothetical absolute point.
We always see things in some broader, narrow,
but still not pointillistic observation.
And so I would suggest that there is an infinite
number of perspectives that could be taken
on the statue.
So unless you have a computer that could compute
an infinite number of perspectives, you're
never going to get the totally complete omnidirectional.
And also, for example, we live at a certain level of time, and we could slow the whole
thing down.
We could speed the whole thing up.
And those also are legitimate perspectives, too, like looking at a flower blossom speed
it up, or looking at an electron move, slowing things down.
All of this part of the perspectives, too.
You're going to end up with no way possible,
conceivable, to have the absolute total, all
perspectives pulled together.
So what you're suggesting, then, is that reality
is virtually infinite because of the various
perspectives that are possible, but the human being is a finite being.
Right.
Yes.
Right.
So we select out from an indeterminately large
plentitude, and a plentitude that is, I don't
want to say infinite, but is indeterminately deep in richness.
And we can penetrate into it in multiple ways,
but it may in principle be inexhaustible.
Yes.
Which raises the question of how can we even
understand each other if we're all always
seeing things differently?
Yeah.
Well, I don't think we all see things all that differently.
I think that there's a lot of variation between
us, of course, but there's also a lot of invariance
or commonality, too.
Like for example, right now we both are engaging
in what we believe is a meaningful conversation
where there is, we believe, some level of
mutual understanding going on because we share
a common language and we share common concepts.
We may have variations in those concepts, too, and we don't get everything that each
of us says, but we get quite a good deal.
And in part that's due to the fact that we
have similar brains, that our minds probably
have similar features and properties to them.
They were all a product and embedded within a giant, ambient earth that was our, what,
mother gestation environment that we emerged out of.
And so it makes sense that we would have a good deal of resonance.
That's not to say that we don't have a lot of
dissonance and disagreement, but I do think
we do make contact and mutually understand each other to a degree at least, yeah.
To a degree.
To a degree.
Yes, to a degree.
Yes.
I think we understand each other.
My sense is we understand each other to a degree.
Of course, people make jokes about the fact,
you know, especially husbands and wives and
partners and say, you don't understand me at all.
You live in a different universe or something.
Yes.
I have a friend who is a Buddhist meditator and
he has a totally different theory or reality
than myself.
But we get into these intense arguments, and
we can't get into intense arguments unless
there's some commonality there that we start from.
I say to him that we live in the same universe,
but we interpret it entirely differently.
But if we didn't live in the same universe, we wouldn't even understand what the hell
each other was talking about.
Yeah.
So I think there's a lot more that we have
in common than we may realize, but of course
there's a lot in which we are different as well too.
That's why we have conversations so we learn from each other.
We learn things that the other one didn't know.
Well, we've raised a lot of interesting issues, and I know there's more to say.
We're going to do a future interview on the reciprocity of mind and reality.
Yes, we are.
Yes, in fact, that will be where I will present
at least an approximation of a way to understand
the relationship between the conscious mind
and the physical world after we've introduced
the puzzle of it.
Well, Tom Lombardo, thank you once again for this fascinating discussion.
Thank you, Jeff.
And thank you for being with us.
Watch the program listings for future discussions with Professor Tom Lombardo.
